The pink, blue, and green vertical lines indicate the widths of the Domain1, Domain2 and Domain3, respectively. The gray dashed line shows the red noise power spectrum.Full size imageDiscussionThe sensitivity experiments show that SN makes the simulations of extreme precipitation more consistent with observations. In particular, the application of SN improves the location and intensity of the upper-level trough, which in turn contributes to a more realistic simulation of the baroclinic structure in the mid-troposphere and related surface cyclone. It affects the moisture transport, responsible for the extreme precipitation. Through this process, SN influences not only dynamical processes but also thermodynamic processes of diabatic ascent and atmospheric moisture that triggers extreme precipitation, although it only nudged horizontal winds above PBL, not temperature and humidity. The improvement of SN generally increases with increasing model domain size. In smaller domains, synoptic-scale waves are not sufficiently resolved in the simulation and the influence of lateral boundary conditions increases. However, its effect varies from event to event. Therefore, the alignment between the dominant horizontal wave scale of the event and the domain size also has a significant influence.The performance improvement by SN is significant in the 202108 and 202007 events where the upper-level trough plays a crucial role. In contrast, the SN has a limited influence on the simulation of the 201009 event. This event is not driven by a synoptic-scale ETC Instead, the abrupt development of the surface trough and baroclinicity is more primarily attributed to the generation of the moisture pathway than to upper-level dynamics. Moreover, the 202108 and 202007 events are primarily influenced by synoptic-scale waves that are well captured within the experimental domains, whereas the 201009 event is triggered by mesoscale disturbances embedded within a larger-scale background flow. In summary, the results of this study reveal that SN has a greater impact on extreme precipitation events driven by the upper-level trough and strong baroclinic instability than in those influenced by surface processes. Its influence is also more pronounced in events whose zonal scales lie between the domain size and the threshold wavelength of SN. Moreover, SN generally contributes to more realistic simulations and reduced ensemble spread. However, its effect can vary depending on the event and domain size, especially when the influence of SN is limited.Practically, within the scope of the specific cases and experimental design of the study, the D2_ON configuration is proposed as the most efficient option for simulating extreme precipitation events where SN is effective (e.g., the 202108 and 202007 events). The regional climate simulation with small domain size degrades the representation of the large-scale features and internal model dynamics due to a lack of spin-up distance for boundary forcing, whereas excessively large domains can lead to strong deviations of the simulation from its lateral boundary conditions28,51,52. In our experiments, the domains that adequately cover the major synoptic-scale zonal waves of events sensitive to SN are Domain1 and Domain2 (Fig. 7). We determined that Domain2 would be more efficient and reasonable than Domain1, as Domain1 includes an abrupt topographical feature on its western boundary due to the Tibetan Plateau53,54 and considering the high horizontal resolution, the computational cost would have been too expensive.This study quantitatively analyzed the impact of SN on extreme precipitation simulations events. Unlike previous studies, more comprehensive and mechanism-based analyses were conducted by considering both synoptic characteristics and domain size. This approach enables a more detailed understanding of how SN can be optimized for different types of extreme precipitation events and domain sizes. There are still areas for improvement, suggesting that further research could build upon the present study to refine the understanding and application of SN in high-resolution modeling. First, further investigation is necessary to validate the consistency of the results across multiple events for each type of extreme precipitation. The reliance of this study on a single representative event for each type may limit the generalizability of its results. Second, the model physics schemes affect precipitation simulations using RCM, with microphysics and PBL schemes being particularly important in convection-permitting simulations55,56,57. In East Asian precipitation simulations, the microphysics scheme significantly influences the hourly maximum precipitation, as different schemes represent and classify hydrometeors (e.g., ice, rain, snow, graupel) in distinct ways, directly affecting the formation and intensity of precipitation particles. The PBL scheme exerts strong control over the average accumulated precipitation by modulating vertical mixing and the turbulent transport of heat and moisture in the lower atmosphere58. This interdependence highlights the need for a more thorough investigation of how different model configurations interact with SN techniques.We also applied SN to hindcast the events, but further research is required to investigate the impact of nudging on forecast fields or global climate models to simulate extreme precipitation45. In addition, the development of quantitative guidelines regarding the horizontal scale and vertical structure of extreme precipitation systems with respect to significant SN effects would be a valuable contribution to the field. Such guidelines could enhance the use of high-resolution models in extreme precipitation research, potentially improving the accuracy and reliability of the simulations.MethodsDataThe European Center for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts reanalysis fifth generation (ERA5) was used as synoptic observation data and initial and lateral boundary forcing for model simulations59. For model evaluation, we utilized two observational datasets of the spatial distribution of precipitation. High-resolution gridded data from Korea Meteorological Administration (KMA 500 m) is a dataset generated by applying a three-dimensional objective analysis technique to assimilate various station observations while incorporating terrain effects60. Integrated Multi-Satellite Retrievals for Global Precipitation Measurement (IMERG) is a NASA product that estimates global surface precipitation rates at a high resolution of 0.1° every half-hour, beginning in 200061. Instead of high spatial resolution KMA 500 m data, which is only available for the South Korean land area, IMERG offers a wide cover area with relatively lower resolution. Thus, both KMA 500 m and IMERG were used to evaluate the spatial distribution of precipitation (Fig. 2), and KMA 500 m data were used to evaluate the time series of precipitation (Fig. 3).Model configurationThe Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model version 4.4 is employed in this study. The WRF model has a single domain with a 3 km horizontal resolution. Based on this high-resolution, we conducted a convection-permitting simulation that explicitly resolves precipitation using microphysics parameterization instead of convection parameterization62,63,64. For the sensitivity experiment, we designed SN and the domain settings. The theoretical basis of the SN option in WRF model version 4.4 is consistent with that of the default SN scheme, in which atmospheric waves longer than the specified cut-off wavenumber are nudged toward the reference values derived from the lateral boundary conditions21,22,65. SN is applied above PBL with coefficient of 3 × 10−4. The nudged wavenumber varies slightly across domains, with a filtering applied to wavelengths longer than approximately 1000 km for each domain (Table S2). We configure the nudging to assimilate only the horizontal wind components (u, v wind), as previous studies66,67 have shown that this approach is sufficient for effective improvement while simplifying the nudging setup. The cut-off wavelength is selected to constrain synoptic patterns and preserve the internal dynamics of the fine scale model49. A coefficient of 3 × 10−4 s−1 was used to apply nudging on an hourly basis. The domain settings are as follows: the largest domain (Domain1) covers the South China Sea and the WNPSH; the second largest domain (Domain2) includes the Yangtze River and WNPSH; and the smallest domain (Domain3) encompasses the Korean Peninsula (Fig. S1). The approximate width of each domain is 4500 km for Domain1, 3000 km for Domain2 and 1800 km for Domain3. The sensitivity experiment consists of six combinations in total, involving the application of SN (ON) and the non-application of SN (OFF) for each domain. The experiment was conducted for three selected events, resulting in eighteen simulations in total. To construct ensemble members, each simulation was performed five times, with the initialization time for each run delayed by 6-hour intervals from the start of the simulation period. Further details of the model configurations are provided in Table S2 of the Supporting Information.Tracking methodThe following methods are utilized in this study to obtain the ETC and IVT center trajectories. First, the trajectory of the ETC center is detected using the approach suggested by Coll-Hidalgo et al.68. First, we prefiltered potential centers in the mean sea level pressure (MSLP) field as locations where the difference between the current MSLP and the average over the previous 5 days is lower than −3 hPa. The point with the lowest MSLP value is selected as the cyclone center. In the next time step, we identify the points where the anomaly below −3 hPa using the same method, but within a restricted radius around the ETC center of previous time step. Among these points, the one with the lowest MSLP value is designated as the ETC center for the next time step. The timestep interval (3-h for 202108 and 202007; 1-hfor 201009) and restricted radius (500 km for 202108 and 202007; 100 km for 201009) are selected based on the spatial scale of each event. The tracking period is set to include the time of maximum hourly precipitation observed.The IVT center is determined as the central point of the IVT pattern associated with the ETC center. First, the IVT pattern is determined by the area exceeding a IVT magnitude threshold within a specified radius around the ETC center (500 km for 202108 and 202007; 300 km for 201009). The IVT magnitude threshold is defined individually for each observation and ensemble member. It is set as the 85th percentile of IVT magnitudes that exceed 100 kg m−1 s⁻1 within the trajectory analysis domain during the two-day period before and after the event date. The 85th percentile was chosen as a reference because it has been used in previous research to define strong and corridor-shaped IVT, the atmospheric river69,70,71. Then, the central point position of the IVT pattern is calculated as the mean latitude and longitude values of the grid points within the IVT pattern. The latitude and longitude are weight-averaged based on the IVT values corresponding to each grid point.

Data availability
              
              Coupled Model Inter-comparison Project Phase 6 data can be downloaded from the Earth System Grid Federation (ESGF) MetaGrid. ERA5 hourly data are available from the Copernicus Climate Data Store72. IMERG half-hourly precipitation data is accessible via the Goddard Earth Sciences Data and Information Services Center (GES DISC)61. High-resolution gridded data from the Korea Meteorological Administration (KMA) is accessible via the KMA Application Programming Interface (API) Hub service60.

              The code used in this study will be provided upon a reasonable request.

items.title: Viaggio tra i “Parchi del Vento”
items.description: Gli impianti eolici ben integrati con il territorio possono essere un importante volano turistico: la Guida Parchi del Vento ti accompagnerà alla sco
items.body:
9 Ottobre 2025

Legambiente

9 Ottobre 2025

News & Storie

Rinnovabili

Viaggio tra i “Parchi del Vento”

9 Ottobre 2025

Legambiente

9 Ottobre 2025

News & Storie

Rinnovabili

Gli impianti eolici ben integrati con il territorio possono essere un importante volano turistico: la Guida Parchi del Vento ti accompagnerà alla scoperta di luoghi fuori dai circuiti più frequentati da percorrere a piedi, in bici o a cavallo, ricchi di storia, arte e prelibatezze culinarie.

Abbiamo selezionato e mappato 29  impianti eolici, di cui 7 nel 2025, e li raccontiamo nella quarta edizione della guida turistica “Parchi del Vento”.
Parchi del vento una guida unica in Italia

Parchi del Vento da nord al sud della Penisola ben racconta il connubio vincente tra innovazione, energia pulita e turismo attraverso la formula del viaggio. Sono tanti e diversi i luoghi dove si possono vedere da vicino questi impianti, scoprendone il loro funzionamento, e allo stesso tempo visitando territori speciali  a piedi, in bici o a cavallo e ricchi di storia, cultura, bellezza ed eccellenze gastronomiche.
I sette nuovi impianti eolici (2 in Molise, 1 in Puglia, 2  in Basilicata, 2 in Sicilia,) inseriti nella guida 2025 e che si aggiungono ai 22 censiti nelle precedenti edizioni, ne sono un perfetto esempio: il parco eolico di Vastogirardi, lungo le creste dell’Appennino molisano, in provincia di Isernia, e quello di Castelmauro in provincia di Campobasso circondato da verde e colline intervallate da piccoli borghi, in Puglia l’impianto eolico Valleverde a Bovino (FG), comune annoverato tra i borghi più belli d’Italia, quello di Partanna (TP), nel cuore della Valle Belice, e quello di Gangi, in provincia di Palermo, tra le Madonie e i monti Nebrodi, e poi in Basilicata l’impianto eolico di “Santa Tecla”, ad Avigliano (PZ), e quello di Tivano, a Lavello (PZ). 
Intorno ai parchi eolici raccontati nella Guida stanno nascendo opportunità sempre più interessanti, come il passaggio del Giro d’Italia. Ma anche impianti perfettamente integrati con vitigni e uliveti e che permettono di riscoprire tradizioni e culture storiche, ormai dimenticati da molti. La dimostrazione che integrare nuovi impianti nel paesaggio è non solo possibile ma anche una sfida che può essere affrontata solo con il consenso delle comunità attraverso forme innovative e affascinanti di valorizzazione delle risorse locali.
Scarica la Guida e inizia il tuo viaggio
Nelle pagine della Guida, oltre alla scheda di presentazione di ogni impianto, si possono trovare info su come arrivare nei luoghi, cosa visitare, dove andare a mangiare, quali percorsi e sentieri fare, il tutto insieme a storie e aneddoti dei territori.
>> Parchi del Vento 2025
Per saperne di più leggi il nostro comunicato stampa

items.title: In Italia mappati 29 impianti eolici, di cui 7 nel 2025, al centro della guida Parchi del Vento 2025
items.description: Viaggio tra i “Parchi del Vento” della Penisola: 29 gli impianti eolici selezionati e mappati in Italia da Legambiente, di cui 7 nel 2025, raccontati
items.body:
9 Ottobre 2025

Legambiente

9 Ottobre 2025

Comunicati stampa

Rinnovabili

In Italia mappati 29 impianti eolici, di cui 7 nel 2025, al centro della guida Parchi del Vento 2025

9 Ottobre 2025

Legambiente

9 Ottobre 2025

Comunicati stampa

Rinnovabili

Viaggio tra i “Parchi del Vento” della Penisola: 29 gli impianti eolici selezionati e mappati in Italia da Legambiente, di cui 7 nel 2025, raccontati nella quarta edizione della guida turistica “Parchi del Vento”.  Legambiente: “Gli impianti eolici, se ben fatti e integrati con il territorio, possono essere anche un importante volano turistico. Fondamentale realizzare nuovi impianti, a terra e in mare, snellendo e velocizzando gli iter normativi e coinvolgendo le comunità locali”.

Dal cuore dell’Alto Molise, tra le creste appenniniche, alla Valle del Belice, in Sicilia, passando all’entroterra lucano e pugliese, l’Italia dei “Parchi del Vento” continua a riservare soprese. Qui, fuori dai circuiti turistici più frequentati, si possono scoprire territori dove gli impianti eolici non solo sono laboratori di transizione ecologica ma anche attrattori di turismo. A raccontarlo sono i 29 impianti selezionati da Legambiente, di cui 7 nel 2025, al centro della quarta edizione della guida turistica “Parchi del Vento”, realizzata dall’associazione ambientalista con il contributo di Agsm AIM, RWE, Winderg, il patrocinio di ANEV, e presentata oggi alla Fiera Internazionale del Turismo a Rimini. Una guida unica in Italia che, dal nord al sud della Penisola, ben racconta il connubio vincente tra innovazione, energia pulita e turismo attraverso la formula del viaggio. Sono tanti e diversi i luoghi dove si possono vedere da vicino questi impianti, scoprendone il loro funzionamento, e allo stesso tempo visitando territori a piedi, in bici o a cavallo e ricchi di storia, cultura, bellezze e prelibatezze culinarie. I sette nuovi impianti eolici (2 in Molise, 1 in Puglia, 2  in Basilicata, 2 in Sicilia,) inseriti nella guida 2025 e che si aggiungono ai 22 censiti nelle precedenti edizioni, ne sono un perfetto esempio: il parco eolico di Vastogirardi, lungo le creste dell’Appennino molisano, in provincia di Isernia, e quello di Castelmauro in provincia di Campobasso circondato da verde e colline intervallate da piccoli borghi, in Puglia l’impianto eolico Valleverde a Bovino (FG), comune annoverato tra i borghi più belli d’Italia, quello di Partanna (TP), nel cuore della Valle Belice, e quello di Gangi, in provincia di Palermo, tra le Madonie e i monti Nebrodi, e poi in Basilicata l’impianto eolico di “Santa Tecla”, ad Avigliano (PZ), e quello di Tivano, a Lavello (PZ). Nelle pagine della guida, oltre alla scheda di presentazione di ogni impianto, si possono trovare info su come arrivare nei luoghi, cosa visitare, dove andare a mangiare, quali percorsi e sentieri fare, il tutto insieme a storie e aneddoti dei territori.
I commenti  
“Per contrastare l’emergenza climatica e migliorare le condizioni sociali del nostro Paese – commenta Katiuscia Eroe responsabile energia di Legambiente – è fondamentale non solo far crescere la produzione da rinnovabili e rendere finalmente il nostro sistema energetico libero da carbone, petrolio e gas, escludendo l’inutile e costoso ritorno al nucleare, ma anche fare in modo che queste tecnologie portino sempre più vantaggi ai territori e alle comunità. Gli impianti eolici non sono né ecomostri né impianti mostruosi come affermato da alcune amministrazioni locali. Con la nostra guida turistica Parchi del Vento, grazie alla collaborazione di diversi partner, raccontiamo a cittadini, turisti, curiosi ma anche imprese e amministrazioni come ciò sia possibile perché un parco eolico, se ben integrato con il territorio, può essere un volano per attirare curiosità verso i territori in cui sono ospitati, valorizzando le attività esistenti. Non dimentichiamo inoltre che, per completare la rivoluzione energetica, è fondamentale spingere sempre più sulle rinnovabili snellendo gli iter normativi e coinvolgendo le comunità locali”.
“Intorno ai parchi eolici che raccontiamo all’interno della Guida Parchi del Vento – aggiunge Sebastiano Venneri, responsabile turismo di Legambiente– stanno nascendo sempre di più opportunità interessanti, come percorsi ciclopedonali, passeggiate a cavallo, il passaggio del Giro d’Italia. Ma anche impianti perfettamente integrati con vitigni e uliveti e che permettono di riscoprire tradizioni e culture storiche, ormai dimenticati da molti. Questi impianti sono la dimostrazione che integrare nuovi impianti nel paesaggio è non solo possibile ma anche una sfida che può essere affrontata solo con il consenso delle comunità attraverso forme innovative e affascinanti di valorizzazione delle risorse locali”.
Dati eolico in Italia
Legambiente ricorda che in Italia l’eolico svolge un ruolo sempre più rilevante, arrivando ad agosto 2025 a quota 13.356 MW di potenza installata, di cui 685 realizzati nel 2024 e 337 nel 2025, in grado di produrre, nel 2024, complessivamente 22.068 GWh/a di energia elettrica, pari al fabbisogno di circa 8,1 milioni di famiglie. Un numero che negli ultimi vent’anni è cresciuto passando da 1.131 MW del 2004 ai numeri attuali, permettendo a questa tecnologia di produrre il 17,2% del totale prodotto da fonti rinnovabili e di fornire un contributo rispetto ai consumi complessivi italiani pari al 7%. Per accelerare la diffusione dell’eolico, sia a terra sia a mare, occorre però snellire e velocizzare gli iter autorizzativi coinvolgendo sempre più comunità e territori, semplificando anche la normativa per il repowering degli impianti esistenti.
Focus Parchi eolici. Molise
Tra i comuni di Castelmauro e Roccavivara, nella provincia di Campobasso, si trova il parco eolico di Castelmauro (CB) di Enel Green Power Italia situato a 800 metri sul livello del mare e circondato da verde e colline. Entrato in funzione nel 2022, l’impianto dispone di 7 aerogeneratori, ognuno da 4,2 MW, per una capacità installata complessiva di 29,4 MW. Nel primo periodo di esercizio ha prodotto in media oltre 55.000 MWh di energia pulita all’anno, fornendo energia pulita e rinnovabile a 3.700 famiglie (circa un quarto delle famiglie del Molise) ed evitando l’immissione in atmosfera di 4.384 tonnellate di CO2.  Merita di essere vistato il borgo di Castelmauro tra dolci colline punteggiate da ulivi, vigneti e boschi secolari, e il castello medievale. Sempre in Molise, lungo le creste dell’Appennino, si trovano i due parchi eolici contigui di Vastogirardi 1 e 2 di Enel Green Power Italia, immersi in un paesaggio ancora integro. Qui le 18 turbine per complessivi 26,35 MW, seguono il ritmo del territorio. Gli aerogeneratori, distribuiti su creste tra i 1.240 e i 1.270 metri sul livello del mare a cavallo tra il Comune di Vastogirardi e quello di Capracotta. Piccoli comuni ricchi di storia e bellezze naturalistiche, come il bosco di Montedimezzo, riconosciuto come parte della Riserva MaB UNESCO: 276 ettari di cerrete e faggete che compongono un ecosistema intatto, percorso da sentieri, abitato da caprioli, lupi e rapaci.
Basilicata
Due i parchi eolici lucani mappati quest’anno nella Guida. Il Parco eolico di Tivano, a Lavello (PZ) composto da sette aerogeneratori, per una potenza complessiva di 14 MW. Insieme, queste moderne turbine producono circa 31 GWh annui di energia pulita, sufficiente a coprire il fabbisogno energetico di circa 10.000 famiglie. Da visitare Lavello, terzo comune più popoloso della provincia di Potenza, ricco di storia e cultura, e celebre per il suo Carnevale. Nell’entroterra lucano, tra terreni argillosi che hanno ospitato storie, pastori e briganti, si erge il Parco eolico di Avigliano capace di produrre oltre 3.500 MWh anno di energia pulita. Denominato “Santa Tecla”, come la storica località che lo ospita, l’impianto ha avuto anche un importante risvolto sociale: dalla sua entrata in funzione, la società Winderg finanzia periodicamente l’APD Atletico Avigliano, squadra di calcio femminile che milita nel campionato di Eccellenza. Avigliano si distingue anche per il contesto naturalistico che lo circonda tra cui anche la sorgente del torrente Tiera, affluente del Basento.
Puglia
In Puglia l’impianto eolico Valleverde, nel Comune di Bovino, in provincia di Foggia, è tra i più recenti ed innovativi nel territorio. Il parco è composto da nove aerogeneratori per una potenza complessiva di 63 MW, in grado di generare 141 GWh annui di energia elettrica, pari al fabbisogno di 45.000 famiglie. Con i suoi 2.893 abitanti, Bovino rientra tra i Borghi più Belli d’Italia e, dal 2013, ha ottenuto la Bandiera Arancione del Touring Club Italiano. Da visitare anche il Castello Ducale.
Sicilia
Nella Valle del Belice, nel Comune di Partanna, l’impianto eolico Partanna, inaugurato da Enel Green Power Italia nel 2021, è formato da sei turbine da 2,4 MW di potenza ciascuna per un totale di 14,4 MW in grado di generare 40 GWh anno di energia pulita, pari al fabbisogno di 10.000 famiglie. Un parco eolico aperto, senza barriere, meta di ciclisti e famiglie. Altro impianto siculo censito nel 2025 è quello di Gangi (PA) che si sviluppa sul crinale del Monte Zimmara a 1250 metri sul livello del mare. È costituito da 32 aerogeneratori, disposti in modo da risultare il più possibile omogenei in altezza, ognuno con una potenza di 850 kW, per una capacità installata complessiva di 27,2 MW. L’impianto negli ultimi 5 anni, dal 2020 al 2024, ha prodotto in media 56 GWh l’anno, sufficienti a soddisfare il fabbisogno energetico di 21.000 famiglie. Inoltre, l’energia pulita prodotta dal vento permette di evitare l’immissione in atmosfera di 42.000 tonnellate di anidride carbonica (CO2) ogni anno. Da visitare il piccolo comune di Gangi, un museo a cielo aperto, insignito nel 2014 come Borgo più bello d’Italia, e circondato dal Parco delle Madonie e da innumerevoli sentieri e percorsi come quello geoturistico del centro storico di Gangi, ideato nel 2011.

items.body:
ECOMONDO 2025 | Gli appuntamenti in Area Forum CIB

9 Ottobre 2025

INCONTRIAMOCI! CI TROVI NEL PADIGLIONE D5 | STAND 314						
				
				
				
																										
				
				
				
							Dal 4 al 7 novembre ritorna l’appuntamento con Ecomondo: non perdere gli appuntamenti dell’Area Forum CIB						
				
				
				
							Il CIB e le aziende Socie espositrici di Ecomondo 2025 animeranno insieme il palco dell’Area Forum, che potrai trovare alle spalle dello stand CIB (Padiglione D5 | Stand 314).						
				
					
		
					
		
				
				
					
			
						
		
				
				
				
						
					
			
						
				
							Martedì 4 novembre						
				
					
		
					
		
				
						
					
			
						
				
					
							
										
						
														
								14.00 - 15.30 La necessità di diffusione e le criticità di accesso alle tecnologie in agricoltura | EVENTO CIB

Il settore primario è chiamato a rispondere a diverse sfide: fornire cibo di qualità e produrlo in modo sostenibile; rispondere alla necessità di ridurre le emissioni e tutelare la fertilità dei suoli; implementare la produzione e l’utilizzo di fonti rinnovabili; interagire con sempre maggiori settori produttivi. Al contempo, il settore primario ha bisogno di misure che favoriscano il percorso di transizione agroecologica. In questo contesto, è necessario interrogarsi su come si possa agevolare l’accesso alle tecnologie disponibili per le numerose aziende agricole italiane che sono pronte a cogliere la sfida. La digestione anaerobica nel tempo ha dimostrato essere una tecnologia in grado di fare da volano per l’introduzione di altre tecnologie innovative nel contesto aziendale agricolo.  Il focus della conferenza è quello di offrire un approfondimento sul tema e rispondere alle domande e alle richieste del settore, proponendo comportamenti virtuosi e buone pratiche.Presidente di sessioneFabio Fava, Presidente CTS EcomondoProgrammaIntroduzione - Fabio Fava, Presidente CTS e Piero Gattoni, Presidente CIBLe misure a supporto della diffusione tecnologica: tra ricerca e applicazione - Angelo Frascarelli, Università degli Studi di Perugia; Paolo Menesatti, Direttore del CREA-IT e Cosimo Pacciani, Osservatorio Smart AgriFood del Politecnico di MilanoL’innovazione tecnologica e le necessità del mondo agricolo - Dialogo tra: Gianmichele Passarini, Vice Presidente CIA; Massimiliano Giansanti, Presidente Confagricoltura e Ettore Prandini, Presidente ColdirettiLe azioni del progetto di Farming for Future come volano per l’innovazione aziendale - Dialogo tra: Diana Lenzi, Presidente Fondazione Farming for Future; Davide Biagi, Soc. items.title: Un futuro sempre meno verde per la PAC
items.description:
Il Parlamento Europeo ha approvato oggi il pacchetto di “semplificazione” della PAC che prevede l’abolizione di molte norme ambientali. 
The post Un f
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il Giaguaro In evidenza Adotta una specie Le Associazioni: “Un autogol per il nostro futuro” Con il voto in plenaria il Parlamento europeo ha votato a favore della proposta della Commissione europea di indebolire l’attuale Politica Agricola Comune (PAC), andando addirittura oltre. Abolendo alcune disposizioni fondamentali delle Buone Condizioni Agricole e Ambientali (GAEC)*, ha dato carta bianca alle pratiche agricole inquinanti e distruttive nel cuore delle aree protette. Decisioni miopi contro l’ambiente Le 13 associazioni che nei giorni scorsi avevano chiesto ai parlamentari europei di dire NO a questo provvedimento dichiarano: “Oggi il Parlamento europeo ha scelto, ancora una volta, di condannare l’agricoltura e gli agricoltori al fallimento totale. Decisioni miopi stanno sacrificando il nostro patrimonio naturale comune – praterie, habitat protetti e suoli sani – che sono fondamentali per l’agricoltura di oggi e di domani.”Il voto di oggi conferma la decisione della commissione AGRI del 24 settembre, il Parlamento europeo ha così indebolito le protezioni per i suoli e per gli ecosistemi, abolendo le misure contro l’erosione (GAEC 5) e eliminando le salvaguardie per le praterie Natura 2000 (GAEC 9), mettendo a rischio gli habitat più preziosi d’europa e decretando che le aziende agricole situate nei siti Natura 2000 sono di per sé e senza ulteriori condizioni conformi alla condizionalità della PAC. Un passo indietro per la natura “Ringraziamo i numerosi parlamentari italiani afferenti ai gruppi dei Verdi Europei, Left e S&D che hanno votato contro questi provvedimenti” aggiungono le associazioni.Avendo anche il Consiglio adottato la propria posizione su questo pacchetto di semplificazione, i negoziati trilaterali dovrebbero iniziare nelle prossime settimane per poi giungere entro l’anno all’adozione del provvedimento. Parallelamente, ricordano le associazioni, stanno proseguono le discussioni sulla proposta della Commissione relativa alla PAC post-2027, la cui proposta è tutt’altro che a favore di una transizione agroecologica.Per questo, concludono le associazioni: “ Chiediamo agli Stati membri e alla Commissione europea di fermare immediatamente questo pericoloso passo indietro per la natura durante i prossimi triloghi. Il futuro degli agricoltori, della natura e dei cittadini europei dipende da questo”.

items.title: Characterization of geothermal resources and estimation of power potential of Badrinath geothermal field northwest Himalaya India
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 09 October 2025

Characterization of geothermal resources and estimation of power potential of Badrinath geothermal field northwest Himalaya India
                    Sameer K. Tiwari1, Árni Ragnarsson2 & Gudni Axelsson3

Scientific Reports

volume 15, Article number: 35291 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate-change impactsEnergyEnvironmental impact

AbstractGeothermal energy is a recognized renewable resource in the present scenario, with over 30 nations generating electricity and 88 using it for heating and heat pumps. Despite its substantial geothermal potential, India has yet to develop this resource because of limited geological exploration, reservoir characterization, and technological constraints. The Indian Himalayas host over 300 geothermal fields, offering a promising avenue for sustainable energy deployment in remote regions. This study evaluates the geothermal potential of the Badrinath geothermal field in the northwest Himalayas using a volumetric heat estimation method integrated with Monte Carlo simulations, addressing uncertainties in subsurface temperature distribution, heat capacity, and fluid recharge. Results indicate a maximum thermal power potential of 39 MWt and an electrical generation potential of 3.0 MWe, demonstrating its viability for small-scale power production. Furthermore, the design of a district heating system for the guesthouse is investigated, with particular attention to optimizing thermal energy transfer efficiency from the geothermal spring to the radiators. Despite extreme winter temperatures reaching − 10 °C, our findings confirm that geothermal water can be effectively utilized for heating applications without endangering the structural integrity of heat exchangers and distribution pipelines. This study represents the first systematic assessment of the Badrinath geothermal field, providing insights for future geothermal energy utilization in the Indian Himalayas.

                        IntroductionThe transition to a carbon-free society depends on the prompt adoption of renewable energy sources (RES) to replace fossil fuels1. While wind and solar energy are cost-competitive, their intermittency limits their capacity to provide reliable baseload power2. Geothermal energy (GTE) emerges as a strong candidate, providing the reliability needed for a sustainable energy future2. Geothermal energy cuts greenhouse gas emissions, supporting United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) goals, and is a sustainable and eco-friendly source3,4. Geothermal energy offers a distinct advantage over other renewable sources because it provides baseload electricity and enables direct utilization5.These unique characteristics have contributed to a significant global increase in geothermal electricity generation and direct applications over the past few decades6,7,8. Geothermal systems are primarily formed because of exothermally heated groundwater driven by convection through fractures, high geothermal gradients, and heat sources such as active tectonic zones (e.g., the Himalayas), volcanic regions, radioactive decay in the Earth’s crust, plate boundaries (continental or divergent), and sedimentary basins9,10,11,12,13,14. India ranks first in energy consumption among developing nations15, and the financial burden of importing fossil fuels has become increasingly unsustainable16. Given the global urgency to address climate change and reduce fossil fuel dependency, the international community is rapidly transitioning to cleaner energy alternatives.The geothermal potential of the Himalayan region, particularly the Garhwal Himalaya, is closely associated with the Main Central Thrust (MCT), which functions as a deep-seated regional heat source9,11,17,18,19. This tectonic structure enables meteoric water to infiltrate to considerable depths, where it is heated and subsequently re-emerges as geothermal activity19. In the study area, geothermal manifestations result from convective water movement in the upper crust within a confined zone, where heat is transferred from the source to the surface under free-surface conditions8,20,21. The structural setup extends approximately 150 km northwest, hosting multiple geothermal resources19,22. These observations are consistent with the high heat-flow anomalies recorded along the MCT in the Garhwal Himalaya, which are associated with numerous hot springs and geothermal fields occurrences11,22.During electricity production, hot water gradually releases its heat, leading to a progressive decline in temperature6. However, the remaining thermal energy can be harnessed for various purposes, such as geothermal cooling, greenhouse farming, space heating, snow melting, geothermal heat pumps, district heating, industrial applications, gas and mineral extraction, and balneotherapy (e.g., lagoon tourism and spa facilities) through a cascade utilization approach. Geothermal resource assessment integrates surface manifestation observations with geoscientific data, including geophysical, geochemical, and geological analyses, to evaluate such potential23.Geothermal resource assessment techniques can be classified into four primary categories: (1) surface thermal flux, (2) volume, (3) planar fracture, and (4) magmatic heat budget. The volume method proves particularly effective due to its broad applicability, the capacity to accurately measure or estimate parameters, manageable error assessment, and the potential to address uncertainties related to recoverability and recharge through future modeling and engineering techniques24. This approach enhances the reliability of geothermal assessments and facilitates sustainable resource management.Estimating geothermal reservoir resources is primarily based on stored heat and volumetric methods, with Monte Carlo simulation widely regarded as the most reliable resource estimation25. The volumetric method evaluates the thermal energy of the system by treating the reservoir as a unified body or dividing it into layers and smaller blocks, each assigned unique values for essential parameters. Key parameters include temperature, porosity, area, thickness, density, and the heat capacity of the fluid and rock matrix26. By applying Monte Carlo simulation, uncertainties in these parameters can be quantified, resulting in more accurate and dependable estimates27. This integration of probabilistic modeling enhances the reliability of resource evaluation and improves decision-making in geothermal energy development.The Monte Carlo method demonstrates how randomness can inform decisions in the face of uncertainty. By repeatedly simulating outcomes for unknown variables, it generates statistically robust results through numerous iterations. For example, rolling a die produces possible outcomes ranging from 1 to 6, but the exact result remains unpredictable, highlighting the role of chance. Similarly, geothermal reservoir parameters such as area, thickness, porosity, and temperature also exist within a range of possible values, each carrying inherent uncertainty27.To achieve accurate results, these uncertainties are modeled using suitable probability distributions (e.g., normal, triangular, uniform, or log-normal) based on the specific characteristics of the geothermal field under investigation. The simulation then generates many random values for each parameter, which are processed iteratively until the results converge into a reliable estimate28. By combining sampling theory with numerical analysis, Monte Carlo simulation has evolved into a powerful tool in computational science, enabling detailed quantification of complex geothermal systems with high precision29.The widespread adoption of Monte Carlo Simulation (MCS) in geothermal research is primarily because of advancements in computing, which enable complex simulations that were previously labor-intensive30,31. This approach allows known geothermal resource characteristics to be projected into potential distributions within the same area30,32. A similar approach, the volumetric heat-in-place method, was initially developed by the United States Geological Survey (USGS)24,33 and later refined by34,35,36.In this study, the volumetric heat-in-place method is combined with Monte Carlo simulation to evaluate uncertainties in estimating the geothermal power potential of the Badrinath geothermal field in the Garhwal Himalaya, India. The assessment incorporates surface manifestations, geochemical and geophysical analyses, geological surveys, and dissolved silica thermometry data. The findings indicate a substantial geothermal potential, suggesting that Badrinath is well-suited for developing a pilot geothermal heating system to meet local energy demands.Geological setup, data, and methodsStudy areaRegions with high geothermal gradients, such as tectonically active areas or plate boundaries, commonly display geothermal anomalies13,19,21,37,38. A geothermal system consists of three key components: a heat source, a reservoir, and a transfer medium, usually a fluid that transports heat to the surface39,40. In India, notable geothermal regions are found in the Himalayas, primarily in deeply incised river valleys and along major geological structures, including the Indus-Tsangpo Suture Zone (ITSZ) and Main Central Thrust (MCT)19. The rapid uplift and erosion of the Himalayan range have resulted in a steep geothermal gradient, mainly driven by hydrothermal activity41,42. Magnetotelluric surveys in the Garhwal region of the northwest Himalayas have identified low-resistivity layers at an average depth of 5 kilometers22. Across India, approximately 300 geothermal springs or fields have been identified, with nearly half (about 120) located in the Himalayan region13,19,37,38.The ITSZ defines the northern boundary of the Himalayan orogeny, while the Himalayan Frontal Thrust (HFT) marks its southern limit43. This region is divided into four primary litho-tectonic units, separated by south-dipping intercontinental thrusts, including the South Tibet Detachment (STD), (MCT), and the Main Boundary Thrust (MBT)44. Notable geothermal activity in the Garhwal Himalaya is concentrated around the MCT zone, which is characterized by high heat flow (130 ± 30 mW/m2) and steep temperature gradients (60° ± 20 °C/km) in the northwest Himalaya45. In the Alaknanda Valley, geothermal features are associated with rock types such as gneiss, schist, and quartzite, all belonging to the Central Himalayan Crystallines46. This site contains gneiss, schist interbedded with calc-silicate, calc-schist, marble, and quartzite, all part of the central crystalline group47. The rocks exhibit asymmetrical folding, forming anticlines and synclines (Fig. 1).Fig. 1Study area with the location of the Badrinath geothermal field (modified after Tiwari et al.19).Full size imageThe Garhwal region of the northwest Himalayas is influenced by the Indian summer monsoon (I.S.M.) and westerly winds, which impact the rivers and streams in the area. The two major proglacial tributaries of the Ganga River system, Alaknanda and Bhagirathi, drain an area of approximately 30,000 km2.Badrinath is home to a single geothermal spring, strategically located on the right bank of the Alaknanda River at a remarkable elevation of 3089 m above sea level. This spring emerges from morainic deposits and is elegantly enclosed by a dome-like structure, along with other permanent installations37. The water, consistently heated to 55.6 °C, flows into various Kunds, serving as a vital resource for pilgrims. It is characteristically tasteless, possesses a distinct sulfurous odor, and occasionally contains gas bubbles, adding to its unique appeal. With an impressive flow rate of approximately 400 L per minute19, this spring not only fulfills spiritual needs but also showcases striking geological features, including visible carbonate deposits near the Tapta Kund, while displaying no ferruginous staining (Fig. 1). Located just 50 m downstream, a second spring with a gentle temperature of 20 °C offers its unique attributes. Its exact origin remains unclear, obscured by surrounding permanent structures. This colorless, slightly sour water is used for practical purposes such as bathing and laundry, with a notable discharge rate of around 190 L per minute. Collectively, these springs enhance Badrinath’s spiritual significance and highlight the region’s fascinating natural phenomena. About 50 m downstream, a lukewarm spring with a temperature of 20 °C also exists. Its precise origin is unclear due to surrounding permanent structures. The water is colorless, slightly sour, and used for bathing and laundry, with a discharge rate of approximately 190 L per minute.The study area has a cold-temperate climate, with snowfall occurring in the upper valleys during December and January, leading to the emergence of springs19,48,49. The study area lies within the inner Himalayan Range, characterized by rugged terrain with steep hills and deep valleys, with elevations ranging from 1400 to 6596 m above sea level. The region has a cold-temperate climate, and snowfall occurs in the upper reaches of the valleys during December and January. The monsoon season, spanning June to September, brings the heaviest rainfall, with an annual average of 1000 mm and 1200 mm48. Additionally, the region is considered highly promising for geothermal energy exploration37.The primary objective of geothermal resource assessments is to determine geothermal resources’ long-term power generation potential while ensuring sustainable utilization for at least 50 years. Accordingly, resource management strategies are designed to support long-term production. These assessments are generally performed during the reconnaissance and exploration phases before drilling, where data are synthesized to identify potential heat sources and host reservoirs, which are later confirmed through exploratory drilling at both shallow and deep levels.Geochemical characteristicsGeothermal systems exhibit rock-water interactions at moderate to high temperatures, with noticeable effects on the Earth’s surface. These interactions are often reflected in the chemical composition of spring water, making it a valuable indicator for studying geothermal systems. The water from Badrinath geothermal spring is mildly neutral, with a pH of 7 to 7.2. At 25 °C, its enormous specific conductivity is 2690 micromhos/cm, while the total dissolved solids (TDS) content is 1910 mg/L. This geochemical characteristic suggests its deep circulation has a meteoric origin19. The surface temperature of the geothermal spring water is recorded at 55.5°C19,37,49. This information is crucial for estimating the accessible resource base, the thermal energy stored in the reservoir, and the recoverable thermal energy. The U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) volumetric “heat in place” method is the most effective way to assess the energy potential of geothermal reservoirs. This reliable approach highlights the substantial resources available for sustainable energy production, underscoring the importance of geothermal energy in renewable solutions50. This study used the volume method to determine the stored energy and produced heat energy of a low-temperature geothermal reservoir in Badrinath. Microsoft Excel was utilized to conduct Monte Carlo simulation studies.The volume method is a highly effective strategy for calculating the thermal energy contained within a specific volume of rock and water, enabling a robust estimation of energy recovery potential. This method accurately determines the thermal energy in the ground by multiplying the volume of a geothermal reservoir by its mean temperature, porosity, and the specific heats of both rock and water. Alternatively, a more straightforward calculation can be employed using the volume, temperature, and an assumed volumetric specific heat51,52.While assessing recoverable thermal energy introduces more complexity, requiring an in-depth understanding of critical reservoir properties such as permeability, this challenge is well worth overcoming. In many cases, the recovery factor can only be approximated53, but the insights gained are invaluable. Notably, the volume method has proven highly effective in estimating thermal energy from low-temperature geothermal fields, underscoring its essential role in advancing sustainable energy solutions35.The volumetric method enhances this by combining MCS with the reservoir volume method24,33,34,35,36. Here, the volumetric method is adopted to estimate the geothermal power potential. The governing equations for total energy E in a geothermal system are given by:$${E}_{res} ={E}_{rock} + {E}_{fluid}$$
                    (1)
                $${E}_{rock }={V(1-\varnothing )}_{{\rho }_{rock} }\times {C}_{rock}\times \left({T}_{res }-{T}_{reference}\right)$$
                    (2)
                $${E}_{fluid }={(V\times \varnothing )}_{{\rho }_{fluid} }\times {C}_{fluid}\times \left({T}_{res }-{T}_{reference}\right)$$
                    (3)
                or$${E}_{fluid }={(V\times \varnothing )}_{{\rho }_{fluid} }\times \left({T}_{res }-{T}_{reference}\right)$$
                    (4)
                where.\({E}_{res}\) = Total energy in the reservoir (J);\({E}_{rock}\) = Energy in the reservoir rock (J);\({E}_{fluid}\) = Energy in the reservoir fluid (J);\({T}_{res}\) = Reservoir temperature (°C);\({T}_{reference}\) = Reference temperature (°C);V = Reservoir volume calculated (m3);Ø = porosity (fraction);Ϲ = Heat capacity (J/kg°C);Ρ = Density (kg/m3);հ = Enthalpy (J/kg).Total recoverable thermal energy is given by:$${E}_{recoverable }=A\times R\times {E}_{res}$$
                    (5)
                where A = Accessibility, and R = Recovery factor.Therefore, thermal power \({P}_{thermal},\) the electrical energy capacity \({E}_{e}\) and power capacity \({P}_{e}\) can be determined by using:$${P}_{thermal} = \frac{{E}_{recoverable}}{\Delta T}$$
                    (6)
                $${E}_{e}={\eta }_{e}\times {E}_{recoverable} \left(above reference temperature\right)$$
                    (7)
                $${P}_{e} =\frac{{E}_{e}}{\Delta T}$$
                    (8)
                where,$${P}_{thermal }=Thermal Power \left(W\right);$$$${P}_{electric }=Power capacity \left(W\right);$$$${E}_{e}=Electircal energy capacity;$$$${\eta }_{e }=Efficiency of the power plant;$$$${\Delta }_{t }=Utilization time period.$$Monte Carlo simulation (MCS)The MCS employs stochastic techniques to assess the impact of measurements and uncertainties on petrophysical results. This technique is preferred because it allows the interpretation model to be processed multiple times with randomly varied parameters. It is often used when the model is complex, nonlinear, or contains uncertain parameters. While the method incorporates various approaches, they generally follow a common pattern. MCS is reliable and widely adopted in geothermal resource assessment, power generation, and techno-economic evaluations. It relies on the reservoir volume method and iterative sampling of probability distributions (e.g., uniform, triangular, Gaussian, PERT). It helps to estimate the probability and cumulative distributions of geothermal resources, with P90, P50, and P10 values representing 90%, 50%, and 10% probability outcomes54,55.Key steps in (MCS) calculation
                  
                    Selection or development of a probability model based on statistical data, analogies, and theoretical considerations.
                  
                  
                    Generation of random numbers and their corresponding random variables.
                  
                  
                    Design and implementation of variance reduction techniques to improve computational efficiency.
                  
                Input parameters for MCSIn this study, the collected data comprise reservoir temperature, formation thickness, porosity, formation rock density, specific heat, and the specific heat of formation fluid. These parameters are characterized using either uniform or triangular probability distributions. For the triangular distribution, each parameter is defined by its minimum, most likely, and maximum values, which makes this distribution particularly suitable when available data are limited35,56. Accordingly, triangular distributions are employed for density, specific heat capacity of rock, geothermal manifestation area, reservoir temperature, project lifespan, and reservoir lithology thickness. Uniform distributions are assigned to rock porosity and recovery factor, whereas constant distributions are used for hot water’s specific heat capacity and density, conversion efficiency, accessibility, and reference temperature. The MCS assessed the geothermal resource and power potential over 25, 35, and 50 years. The MCS runs with at least 100,000 iterations in Microsoft Excel. Accessibility is constant for this study.Recovery factorThe geothermal recovery factor is the ratio of heat recovered at the wellhead to the heat stored in the reservoir. This value typically depends on several factors, including the permeability structure, the characteristics of the wells, and the reservoir’s thermal and hydraulic boundary conditions. As a result, the recovery factor is not an intrinsic property used in resource evaluation with the volumetric method; rather, it reflects the actual operational characteristics of a reservoir63.Currently, there is no information regarding the permeability characteristics of the potential resource, as there is no evidence of permeable reservoirs in the locations being studied19,37. Surface data suggest the Badrinath field could initially support a 0.7 MWe plant for 50 years.Fig. 4Relative frequency plots of volumetric reserve estimates for the Badrinath field over 50 years.Full size imageSensitivity analysis of MCS inputAmong the key input parameters in our Monte Carlo simulations, the reservoir’s volume, temperature, and recovery factor are the most uncertain variables. Their significant influence on the simulated capacity output is reflected in the thermal power, electrical energy capacity, and power capacity described in Eqs. (1, 3, 6, 7) and the minimum–maximum range in Table 3. While we established triangular distributions for the Badrinath reservoir based on credible data, variations in the mode (the most likely value) can significantly affect the final results. To illustrate this, we conducted additional Monte Carlo iterations, adjusting each zone’s most likely recovery factor and volume. In this analysis, we treated volume as an independent variable rather than deriving it from reservoir area and thickness. The most likely recovery factor was adjusted from 0.1 to 0.2, while the minimum and maximum values for the triangular and uniform distributions were kept constant per Table 3. All other distributions remained unchanged, highlighting the critical importance of precise input parameters for reliable simulation outcomes.District heating potential of the Badrinath geothermal fieldThis study evaluates the geothermal potential of the Badrinath field using the volumetric method and Monte Carlo simulation to determine its feasibility for space heating in the Garhwal region of the northwest Himalaya. Geothermal water and steam are sustainable energy sources for electricity generation and direct use. Electricity generation utilizes geothermal heat (130 °C to 300 °C) to produce mechanical energy, achieving 10% to 30% efficiencies. Direct uses, such as space heating, attain 50% to 80% of thermal efficiencies68. Co-generation systems optimize energy use by integrating both methods. District heating systems, effective in cold regions, offer cost-efficient heating solutions. This study also assesses the potential for geothermal house heating in Badrinath, comparing it to successful European models, particularly from Iceland. The volumetric assessment shows promising potential, with estimates indicating the field could generate at least 3 MWe of electricity and 39 MWt of thermal power upon successful drilling. This makes it suitable for a geothermal heating system at a government guesthouse managed by the Garhwal Mandal Vikas Nigam in Badrinath town. The geothermal water’s chemical composition, primarily Na–HCO₃, is detailed in Table 1.Design and heating load assessment of the siteThe government guesthouse is the primary commercial building in Badrinath town, comprising 20 rooms and a dormitory with over 300 beds. It is located 300 m from the geothermal resource, with an aerial distance of 200 m from the spring. The guesthouse spans 1000 m2 (50 × 20 m) with a volume of 8000 m3 (50 × 20 × 8 m). The heat demand of the building is primarily influenced by outdoor temperature, though factors like wind speed and solar radiation also play a role. Input parameters indicate that the maximum outdoor temperature reaches 15 °C (the required room temperature for human comfort) for only one month annually.In contrast, sub-zero temperatures persist for over six months, necessitating space heating. Studies estimate the Badrinath geothermal reservoir temperature between 130 and 150 °C. Heat will be supplied using wall-mounted steel radiators, though their quantity is yet to be determined. Return water temperature sensors will regulate the radiator flow rate. The system will include steel pipes (1 or 1.5 inches in diameter) for internal circulation and pre-insulated plastic pipes (PEX, 52 mm diameter, 300 m long) for outdoor installation. The heating system is designed for a peak load of 320 kWt.The town has a stable electricity supply, minimizing the risk of power failure affecting pump operation. To enhance reliability, 1 MW solar power units will be installed. Since the hot spring is at a lower elevation (5 m) than the guesthouse, pumping is required to transport the geothermal water. A schematic of the system is shown in Fig. 5, illustrating key components: hot springs, heat exchangers, pumps, transmission pipes, and radiators. The maximum discharge rate of the spring is 430 L per minute, with a natural outflow temperature of 55.5 °C, currently used for tourism-related bathing. Chemical analysis of the geothermal water19 confirms its suitability for direct-use heating without scaling or corrosion risks in pipes or radiators. However, a heat exchanger system will be implemented to prevent freezing in outdoor pipes during low ambient temperatures. In case of pump failure, a closed-loop system will circulate freshwater mixed with 30% ethylene glycol antifreeze through the radiators. Direct through-flow of geothermal water would be more efficient if the spring were higher, but this is not the case. Among various heat exchanger types, the brazed plate heat exchanger is preferred because of:Fig. 5Proposed schematic diagram for space heating for the government guesthouse.Full size image(i) Compact design with a high power-to-volume ratio (m3/kW); (ii) Enhanced heat transfer efficiency because of high turbulence (even at Reynolds numbers as low as 10–400), which also prevents fouling; (iii) Lightweight and easy handling compared to other systems. A similar geothermal heating system was successfully implemented at Chumathang, Ladakh, in 2014, where a small-scale heating system was deployed68. The heat exchanger will be housed in a small hut near the spring in Badrinath. Hot-dip galvanized steel pipes will carry water to the 370 W self-priming electric pump, circulating water through the heat exchanger. The winter design conditions are 55.5 °C inlet and 30 °C outlet temperatures, with the outlet water discharged into the natural runoff. Detailed heat loss and heat exchange calculations are provided in the supplementary material (Appendix 1 from Tables 5–11).ConclusionsThis paper presents the first evaluation of geothermal resources and power potential estimation of the Badrinath geothermal field. Based on the available published geological and geophysical data, the volumetric heat in place method combined with the Monte Carlo simulation approach was applied in the most promising zones identified in the literature of India. Geo-thermometric analysis indicates subsurface reservoir temperatures between 100 and 140 °C, confirming the field’s suitability for low-temperature geothermal development. Using the volumetric method combined with Monte Carlo simulations to account for uncertainties, the study estimated power potential under 25, 35, and 50-year utilization scenarios. For 25 years, thermal power output (MWt) was estimated at P10: 39.5, P50: 27.3, and P90: 18.0, with corresponding electric power output (MWe) of 3.2, 2.2, and 1.4.Badrinath geothermal field could initially support a 1.04 MWe plant for 35 years. For 50 years, thermal output was 19.7, 13.7, and 9.0 MWt, with electric output at 1.6, 1.1, and 0.7 MWe. These results demonstrate that the available geothermal resource can provide a consistent and sustainable source of electricity and heating for Badrinath, significantly reducing reliance on fossil fuels. However, the current geothermal spring discharge is adequate to meet the heating needs of the guesthouse. Overall, this study confirms that the geothermal resource in the Garhwal Himalaya presents a viable and sustainable energy solution for high-altitude, remote regions.Despite considerable geological uncertainties, the techno-economic analysis strongly demonstrates that geothermal energy is a reliable, cost-effective, and cost-competitive solution. It is crucial in propelling India toward its ambitious carbon–neutral and green energy goals.

items.title: Enhancing hydropower resilience through dynamic rule curve modifications under climate change in the Sunkoshi multipurpose scheme, Nepal
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 09 October 2025

Enhancing hydropower resilience through dynamic rule curve modifications under climate change in the Sunkoshi multipurpose scheme, Nepal
                    Ram Krishna Regmi1, Arish Shrestha1, Vishan Dahal1 & …Subash Kunwar1 Show authors

Scientific Reports

volume 15, Article number: 35317 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate changeHydrology

AbstractAmid Nepal’s expanding hydropower sector, the Sunkoshi Multipurpose Scheme stands as a pivotal inter-basin transfer project. As the country seeks to maximize its abundant water resources, strengthening hydropower resilience against the inevitable impacts of climate change is imperative for ensuring long-term energy sustainability. This study conducts a comprehensive assessment of climate change impacts on the Sunkoshi River Basin and proposes an adaptive management strategy through dynamic rule curve modifications, optimizing reservoir operations in response to projected shifts in water availability across different time horizons of the 21st century. Seven bias-corrected General Circulation Models (GCMs) (ACCESS-CM2, BCC-CSM2-MR, CanESM5, EC-Earth3, MPI-ESM1-2-HR, MPI-ESM1-2-LR, and NorESM2-MM) were adopted for the projection of climate variables under Shared Socio-Economic Pathways (SSP)245 and SSP585 scenarios which were further utilized for the projection of future discharge in the Soil and Water Assessment Tool (SWAT). The anticipated inflow data served as input to the Hydraulic Engineering Center- Reservoir System Simulation (HEC-ResSim) software to simulate the reservoir operation and propose modified rule curves for Sunkoshi No.1, Sunkoshi No.2, Sunkoshi No.3, and Dudhkoshi hydropower projects for the time frame of 2030s, 2060s, and 2080s. Six different rule curves were proposed and average yearly energy generations were maximized ranging from 25.5%, 61.07%, 71.26%, and 10.50% for Sunkoshi No.3, Sunkoshi No.2, Sunkoshi No.1, and Dudhkoshi power plants respectively. These results could be helpful for long-term planning, urging policymakers to integrate dynamic rule curve modifications in the broader context of sustainable energy production and climate change adaptation.
